Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lip-cup; interior, from outside: black zone; alternating red and black tongue frieze, between sets of four black lines; in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of possibly two male figures and an Amazon, all to right, with the Amazon no doubt turning back; of male figure(s), only one bent leg and one greaved leg are preserved; of Amazon, added white leg in red greave remains); exterior black with part of reserved band at outer break.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Amazons are a common motif on Little-Master cups. The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.202.1894.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 386, no. B547)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 41, pl. XXI, no. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1346) (phase 3)
